awd_titl_txt: Developing K-12 Education Guidelines for Artificial Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing guidelines for teaching and learning about artificial intelligence (AI) in K-12 school settings. Though AI is a quickly emerging field of research with broad applications in the STEM workforce and industry generally, there are few curriculum standards or educational guidelines for introducing pre-college students to fundamental knowledge and skills relating to the field of AI.  This project will address the emerging need for greater guidance in this field by bringing together specialists in AI from academia and industry with specialists representing K-12 education to draft guidelines for teaching and learning about AI across the grade bands of K-12 schools. The draft guidelines will then be reviewed by a larger interest group representing specialists in AI and computer science, as well as representatives of K-12 educators more broadly and the general public. Feedback from this larger interest group will be used to refine the guidelines for broader dissemination.  In addition to  developing initial guidelines for AI education at the pre-college level, the project will create an online directory of resources that can be used by K-12 teachers to develop instructional experiences in AI for their students.

The project team is working in association with the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) and the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) to model AI guidelines after CSTA's K-12 Computer Science Standards released in 2017. The project Steering Team includes members of AAAI and CSTA, as well as broad representation of AI scholars nationwide and experienced K-12 teachers across all grade bands.  Efforts are being made to ensure that culturally relevant resources are identified and readily available to support implementation of the forthcoming guidelines with all student populations nationwide.  The project team includes a Steering Committee that guides the project, and a larger Working Group consisting of experienced K-12 teachers at all grade levels and AI specialists representing academia and industry.  An Advisory Group representing AI education nationally and internationally will provide additional guidance to the project.  The project will employ mailing lists, a project website, and social media to engage the broader community of interested scholars, educators, researchers, and members of the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The three main goals of this project were to (1) develop national guidelines for teaching artificial intelligence in K-12; (2) create a curated resource directory of AI materials appropriate for K-12 students and teachers; and (3) foster development of a community of K-12 AI education researchers, resource developers, and teachers.

One of the first results of the project was a list of "Five Big Ideas in AI" and an accompanying infographic poster. These big ideas serve as the organizing framework for the guidelines and have been widely adopted by curriculum developers both in the US and internationally. The poster is now available in 16 languages.

The guidelines are organized as a set of grade band progression charts, one for each big idea, with the columns being the grade bands (K-2, 3-5, 6-8, and 9-12) and the rows being the concepts and subconcepts that make up that big idea. Each cell defines what students in that grade band should know about that particular concept (the "essential understanding"), and what they should be able to do with it (the "learning objective"). All five progression charts have been publicly released and feedback is being collected for future revisions.

The second project goal, a curated resource directory, is available on the AI4K12.org web site. It is a growing list of books, videos, online demonstrations, curriculum modules, teacher professional development courses, and similar resources.

The third project goal, fostering a community of AI education researchers, resource developers, and teachers, was realized in several ways. The AI4K12 mailing list established by this project and maintained by AAAI has hundreds of subscribers. The project organized two symposia on AI education offered as part of the AAAI Fall Symposium series in 2018 and 2019. A new special track was added to the EAAI conference on "Tools for Teaching AI in K-12". Project members Touretzky and Gardner-McCune served as the track co-chairs in 2021, 2022, and 2023. Information sessions and professional development activities were held at the ISTE, CSTA, AAAI, and SIGCSE conferences. The project also collaborated with the broader CS education community through ECEP and CS4ALL to incorporate AI into CS education.

Several national leaders in AI education arose from their involvement in this project. One is now Chief Operating Officer at aiEDU, and another is helping to shape Maryland's AI education efforts at the Maryland Center for Computing Education. Serving in the AI4K12 Working Group has prepared 22 teachers, 2 university researchers, and 1 administrator for their current roles advancing AI education in their states.

A supplement to the original award provided funding to hold a workshop for state education officials to consider how to incorporate AI education into their state's K-12 education standards. The "State of AI Education In Your State" planning workshop was held in January 2021, with delegations representing 27 states and 3 US territories. Several follow-on meetings were held to track the progress of state-level efforts and provide mutual support. A report on the state of AI education in the US as of 2022 is being prepared for publication.

Finally, the AI4K12 Steering Committee, consisting of David Touretzky, Christina Gardner-McCune, Fred Martin, and Deborah Seehorn received the 2022 AAAI/EAAI Outstanding Educator of the Year Award in recognition of their efforts on this project.
